== Belkin F5D8010 ==

The following guide was originally published on <nowiki>[[http://welcometoubuntu.blogspot.com|Welcome to Ubuntu]]</nowiki>.

The guide was written at the Fiesty-Fawn timeframe (7.0.4). Paul Ryan provides numerous update pointers for a Karmic Koala context (9.10) as a comment on the <nowiki>[[http://welcometoubuntu.blogspot.com/2007/10/howto-get-airgo-based-wifi-enabled.html|original blog post]]</nowiki> (March 2010 timeframe).

=== Introduction ===

This guide is a walkthrough for installing WiFi cards that are based upon the TrueMIMO Pre-N technologies. Wireless cards with this chipset (Airgo AGN100) have been particularly difficult to install under Linux due to the chipset's schematics being closed-source. Using the official Ubuntu Documentation on <nowiki>[[WifiDocs-Driver-Ndiswrapper |ndiswrapper]]</nowiki>  & the <nowiki>[[http://tinyurl.com/7earu|ndisWrapper]]</nowiki> page on Sourceforge, I have created a set of instructions to install this card. There are two sets of instructions: one if you can  currently get online through a wired connection, and one if you cannot get online through a wired connection and must either dual-boot with Microsoft Windows or download the files on a different system. If you can do the wired connection method, it is the preferred method.

=== Other cards these instructions may work with ===
These instructions may work on, but are not guaranteed to work for the following cards except for the Belkin F5D8010:

* Linksys WPC511GX
* Linksys WMP54GX
* Netgear WGM511
* Buffalo WLI-CB-G108
* AeroGuard AGN1023PC
* Planex CQW-NS108AG
* Planex CQW-NS108G
* Samsung X20 Laptop
* GemTek WPCO-131G
* Corega CG-WLCB108GM

=== Online Instructions ===

==== Installing ndisWrapper ====

# Open Terminal.
# Type (or copy/paste) the following line into terminal:
    <code>     lspci -nn</code>
1. Look for the following:
    <code>     03:00.0 Ethernet Controller: Airgo Networks Inc AGN100 802.11 a/b/g True MIMO Wireless Card [17cb:0001] (rev 01)</code>
       If the line is not present, these instructions will not work for you.
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following lines into Terminal:
    <pre>
     sudo modprobe -r ndiswrapper
    sudo apt-get --purge remove ndiswrapper-utils
    sudo rm -r /etc/ndiswrapper/
    sudo rm -r /etc/modprobe.d/ndiswrapper
    sudo rm /lib/modules/$(uname -r)/kernel/drivers/net/ndiswrapper/ndiswrapper.ko</pre>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following line into Terminal:
    <code>     sudo apt-get install linux-headers-$(uname -r)</code>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following line into Terminal:
    <code>     sudo apt-get install dh-make fakeroot gcc-3.4 build-essential</code>
# Navigate to <nowiki>[[http://tinyurl.com/6u3cw|Sourceforge]]</nowiki> to download the latest version of ndisWrapper.
# Save the file you download in your Home folder
# Type (or copy/paste) the following lines into Terminal:
    <pre>
     tar xvfz ndiswrapper-[current version].tar.gz
    cd ndiswrapper-[current version]</pre>
    (Where <code>[current version]</code> is the version number of the file you downloaded. i.e.: ndiswrapper-1.52.tar.gz)
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following lines into Terminal:
    <pre>
     sudo make uninstall
    sudo make</pre>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following lines into Terminal:
    <pre>
     fakeroot
    sudo make install</pre>

==== Installing the Drivers ====
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following into a terminal to download the drivers:
    <code>     wget http://77.91.202.10/~alpoimco/Satanas/belkin_pre-n.tar.gz</code>
    Mirror (If the first link is down):
    <code>     wget http://www.someawe.com/uploads/belkin_pre-n.tar.gz</code>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following into a terminal to extract the drivers you just downloaded:
    <pre>
     tar xvfz belkin_pre-n.tar.gz
    cd belkin_pre-n</pre>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following line into terminal:
    <code>     echo 'blacklist bcm43xx' | sudo tee -a /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist</code>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following line into terminal:
    <code>     sudo ndiswrapper -i NetAni.inf</code>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following line into terminal:
    <code>     ndiswrapper -l</code>
1. Look for the following:
    <pre>
     tmimo3p: driver installed
                 device (17CB:0001) present</pre>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following into Terminal to activate the driver:
    <pre>
     sudo depmod -a
    sudo modprobe ndiswrapper</pre>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following into Terminal to check for errors:
    <code>     tail /var/log/messages</code>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following into Terminal to open the Network Manager:
    <code>     gksudo network-admin</code>
# Verify the connection labeled "Wireless connection" says "Roaming mode enabled" beneath it.
# Perform the following steps if it does not say "Roaming mode enabled:"
    a. Click the Wireless connection to highlight it.
    a. Click the Properties button to open the properties window.
    a. Click the check box next to Enable roaming mode and click Ok.
    a. Verify that the wireless connection now says "Roaming mode enabled."
# Click the close button on the Network manager to close it and return to the Terminal.
# Type (or copy/paste) the following into Terminal to create an alias for your wireless card:
    <code>     sudo ndiswrapper -m</code>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following into Terminal to open the modules list:
    <code>     gksudo gedit /etc/modules</code>
1. Type the following at the end of the text document that loads (if not already present):
    <code>     ndiswrapper</code>
1. Reboot your system to make sure everything is in full working order.

==== Installing ndisWrapper and the drivers ====

# Open terminal on your Ubuntu system.
# Type (or copy/paste) the following into Terminal to install ndisWrapper:
    <pre>
     sudo dpkg -i ndiswrapper-common_*.deb
    sudo dpkg -i ndiswrapper-utils*.deb
    sudo dpkg -i --force-depends ndisgtk_*.deb</pre>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following into a terminal to extract the drivers you just downloaded:
    <pre>
     tar xvfz belkin_pre-n.tar.gz
    cd belkin_pre-n</pre>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following line into terminal:
    <code>     echo 'blacklist bcm43xx' | sudo tee -a /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist</code>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following line into terminal:
    <code>     sudo ndiswrapper -i NetAni.inf</code>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following line into terminal:
    <code>     ndiswrapper -l</code>
1. Look for the following:
    <pre>
     tmimo3p: driver installed
                 device (17CB:0001) present</pre>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following into Terminal to activate the driver:
    <pre>
     sudo depmod -a
    sudo modprobe ndiswrapper</pre>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following into Terminal to check for errors:
    <code>     tail /var/log/messages</code>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following into Terminal to open the Network Manager:
    <code>     gksudo network-admin</code>
# Verify the connection labeled "Wireless connection" says "Roaming mode enabled" beneath it.
# Perform the following steps if it does not say "Roaming mode enabled:"
    a. Click the Wireless connection to highlight it.
    a. Click the Properties button to open the properties window.
    a. Click the check box next to Enable roaming mode and click Ok.
    a. Verify that the wireless connection now says "Roaming mode enabled."
# Click the close button on the Network manager to close it and return to the Terminal.
# Type (or copy/paste) the following into Terminal to create an alias for your wireless card:
    <code>     sudo ndiswrapper -m</code>
1. Type (or copy/paste) the following into Terminal to open the modules list:
    <code>     gksudo gedit /etc/modules</code>
1. Type the following at the end of the text document that loads (if not already present):
    <code>     ndiswrapper</code>
1. Reboot your system to make sure everything is in full working order.

==== If roaming mode doesn't work ====

Follow the wireless security guide in the <nowiki>[[http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=318539|forums]]</nowiki>.
